awd_titl_txt: Symposium: Nanomaterials and Nanomanufacturing for Sustainability; 2018 Materials Research Society Fall Meeting; Boston, Massachusetts; 25-30 November 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is for the partial support for the Nanomaterials and Nanomanufacturing for Sustainability Symposium at the Fall Materials Research Society (MRS) Meeting in Boston, Massachusetts, 25-30 November 2018. The award provides funds for the conference travel and registration expenses of graduate students, postdocs, early career faculty, and underrepresented minority and women researchers. The MRS Meeting is the premier international conference, where academic, government laboratory and industry representatives participate, speak and discuss topics in advanced materials and manufacturing. This Symposium's topic is Sustainable Nanotechnology, with a specific focus on Nanomaterials and Nanomanufacturing. The Symposium advances knowledge in in emerging and advanced nanomaterials and nanomanufacturing for sustainability and environment, which impacts the nation's prosperity and health. The Symposium is a networking and workforce development opportunity by providing a forum for students and young faculty to meet attendees from industry, government labs and other academic institutions. 

The Nanomaterials and Nanomanufacturing for Sustainability Symposium's goal is to advance knowledge in emerging and advanced nanomaterials and nanomanufacturing for cleaner, more efficient technologies for transportation, energy management, environmental monitoring and depollution. The topics are nanomaterials and nanomanufacturing for sustainability; air, soil and water quality management; renewable energy; lighter and stronger materials; nanotoxicology; and life cycle analysis. The symposium is a venue for tutorials, keynote lectures, oral and poster presentations, and networking for students, faculty and industry. It is a forum to learn new methods and exchange research results. A novel sub-event involves rapid-fire presentations to give an opportunity to all poster presenters to pitch their poster for 1 minute during the oral sessions and on a LCD screen next to the outside signage of the session. Winning pitches are recognized.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This symposium covered recent advances in the development of nanomaterials and nanomanufacturing for cleaner, more efficient technologies for transportation, energy management, environmental monitoring and depollution. The topics were nanomaterials development in: (1) Sustainable manufacturing; (2) Air, soil and water quality management; (3) Renewable energy technologies; (4) Lighter and stronger materials; (5) Nanotoxicology; (6) Life cycle analysis.

The unique virtual student competitions, oral presentations for the poster presenters, and panel discussions about difficulties in research attracedt a larger attendance of graduate students, postdocs, and junior faculty, especially from the under-represented groups.  Funding support from NSF was critical to the success of the Symposium, the broad participation of the under-represented groups, and creating a set of unique activities during the MRS meeting. The organizing committee selected high-quality contributions during abstract review. The organizers (three of whom are women and all of them with strong international exposure) were strongly committed to recruit and promote minorities to attend the meeting.

A broad topic of “nano on sustainability” brings together a wide spectrum of researchers to create an interdisciplinary session. A central strategy for this program is to give more visibility opportunities to young researchers in this emerging field, as well as to reinforce an open dialogue within the corporate technical leaders.

this symposium offered unique opportunities for early career and young researchers, as well as networking and shared knowledge with various stakeholders, including corporate sector views of life cycle analyses to foster new synergies efforts on research and development between next generations and corporate sector. Exposure and emphasis, bringing in new points of view, for example from the corporate leaders and senior scientists, stimulated and catalyze both individual and collaborative efforts amongst materials researchers at all levels.

A total of 11 internationally renowned invited speakers presented their latest research findings in the field at the symposium, including Benjamin Hsiao (Stony Brook University, USA), Caue Ribeiro de Oliveira (Embrapa Instrumentation, Brazil), Emmanuel Flahaut (Universite Paul Sabatier, France), Eric Detsi (University of Pennsylvania, USA), Husam Alshareef (King Abdullah University of Science and Technology, Saudi Arabia), Kenneth Loh (University of California - San Diego, USA), Khershed Cooper (National Science Foundation, USA), Meifang Zhu (Donghua University, China), Phoebe Tan (Raynergy Tek, Inc, Taiwan), Ray Baughman (The University of Texas at Dallas, USA), and Yury Gogotsi (Drexel University, USA).

The NM04 Symposium - Nanomaterials and Nanomanufacturing for Sustainability received 225 abstracts. A large number of graduate students gave oral and poster presentations. All sessions of the NM04 Symposium were well-attended and well-received. The NM04 symposium had unique activities: rapid-fire presentations, 24-7 video competition and two best posters per evening.

Ten (10) articles have been submitted to MRS Advances for F18 Symposium NM04, and to date, nine of which have been published.

Funds received from NSF were used exclusively for the LCD rental, support of female and early-career attendees (8), and symposium organizers (2). Among the 10 people who received support from NSF, 3 were graduate students (including 2 outstanding student presentation awardees), 2 were postdocs, 1 was researcher at an institute, 1 was faculty and 1 was engineer in the industry.
